mdRecord.dcterms:title: Petition, George Washington's estate as a national property, 1846 August 5
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Petition sent from Washington, D. C., expressing the great importance of George Washington's home and tomb to the public and the petitioner's desire for it to become a 'National property.' Formally request of the present owner [John A. Washington III], "to specify in writing, the terms on which this Nation may become possessed of one hundred, or the entire number of acres, composing the Estate known to the world as the Burial place of Washington." Signed by 23 petitioners including U. S. Vice President George M. Dallas, several U.S. cabinet members [James Buchanan, Secretary of State], senators, congressmen, the mayor of Washington, D. C., and a publisher of the congressional debates. Some of the identified names include: George M. Dallas, U. S. Vice President; Senator Revendy Johnson (MD); Congressman James Black (PA); Senator Daniel R. Atchison (MO); Senator Chester Ashley (AR); Congressman George Washington Hopkins (VA); Congressman William W. Woodworth (NY); Mayor of Washington, D. C. William Winston Seaton; Senator Sam Houston (TX); Senator William Upham (VT); Senator James T. Morehead (KY); Edmund Burke, Commissioner of Patents under President Polk; John C. Rives, publisher of the Congressional Debates; James Buchanan, Secretary of State; George Bancroft, Secretary of the Navy; and Senator Robert J. Walker (MS). Autograph document signed, 2 pages.
